prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a)

para.paratext: Consideration by the transferor court of a motion to transfer one or more of the actions before the Panel under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) may have a number of impacts on the Panel's decision. As a threshold matter the Panel has observed that the decision to transfer actions for all purposes is different from the Panel's decision on a motion to transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407.[1] The Panel has also recognized, however, that the questions are similar and has considered the pendency, denial, and the grant of a motion to transfer under § 1404(a) in deciding the question of transfer under § 1407 and in selection of a transferee district.[2]

The pendency of a motion to transfer under § 1404(a) will not necessarily preclude transfer under § 1407 nor postpone consideration of the motion by the Panel.[3] The Panel has, however, deferred hearing or ruling on a motion for transfer where the pending motion to transfer under § 1404(a) would “moot” the matter before the Panel.[4] The pendency of multiple transfer motions under § 1404(a) can be a notable factor.

Denial of a motion for transfer under § 1404(a) will also not prevent the Panel from considering a motion for transfer under § 1407.[5] As a practical matter, however, the Panel has noted that many of the same considerations apply and it will consider the decision of the transferor court on the transfer question before the Panel. Conversely, the granting of a motion under section 1404(a) may indicate to the Panel another judicial judgment that that transferee forum is appropriate for section 1407 transfer by the Panel.[6]

Neither the pendency nor denial of a motion for transfer under § 1404(a) directly affects the Panel's selection of a transferee district. The grant of a motion to transfer for all purposes may be a factor of interest to the Panel. In one case the Panel observed:

We think that the District of Connecticut stands out as the most appropriate transferee forum. At the time the motion was filed there were no private civil actions pending in Connecticut, but since that time all three of the actions originally commenced in the Northern District of Illinois have been transferred to the District of Connecticut for all purposes pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a). Where transfer under § 1407 is preceded by transfer of some cases under § 1404(a), the district selected by the transferor judge or judges and the reasons given therefore are entitled to great weight in selecting the most appropriate district for transfer of the remaining actions under § 1407.[7]
In a similar decision, the Panel stated:

The two actions already pending in that district have been transferred there for all purposes under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a). The district selected by the Section 1404(a) transferor judges and the reasons given therefor are normally entitled to great weight in selecting the most appropriate transferee district for Section 1407 proceedings.[8]

This factor has been considered by the Panel in other decisions as well.[9] The Panel has also declined to follow the decision of a transferor court transfer order.[10] This is especially true where the litigation pending in that transferor court did not present the same complexity of issues as the entire litigation pending before the Panel.[11] The Panel has also considered the denial of a motion to transfer cases to a district for trial under § 1404(a) as affecting the Panel's judgment on selection of an appropriate transferee district.[12]

A decision on a motion to transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) may affect the views of the parties toward transfer by the Panel. In one case the only party opposing transfer by the Panel changed its position and agreed to transfer after a trial court judge entered an order transferring that party's action under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) to the transferee district for all purposes.[13]

Another compelling role that 1404(a) can play in the selection of a transferee district arises in the aftermath of the Supreme Court's Lexecon decision.[14] Because of the Court's ruling the restricts the ability of the transferee court to transfer cases to itself under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a), the Panel may have a preference for transferring cases to a district where venue might properly have been laid at the time of filing the case. In so doing, the Panel makes it at least possible for the transferor court, upon remand by the Panel, to transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) to the MDL transferee judge. This retransfer has been approved by some courts, although the Supreme Court did not explicitly bless it in Lexecon.[15]

Although the Panel will not decide the question of 1404(a) transfer, it has appeared to endorse consideration of transfer under 1404(a), either to the parties or the court where the actions are pending.[16]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The relationship of transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 and change of venue under other statutes is discussed in §§ 3:4 (power to transfer) & 5:3 (transfer).
The role of this factor in the question of transfer, rather than selection of a transferee district, is discussed in § 5:48.
The effect on transfer of the pendency of a motion in the transferor court is discussed in § 5:54.

See, e.g., In re Scientific Drilling Intern., Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2014). “Mootness” may affect timing of transfer as well. See § 5:54. But see In re Gas Vent Pipe Antitrust Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 799 (J.P.M.L. 1974) (transfer ordered despite all actions being before same judge).
See In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404, 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1971). Accord In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376, 382 (J.P.M.L. 1972).

See, e.g., In re Athena Universal Life II Cost of Insurance Increase Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 3d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017); In re: Gerber Probiotic Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 899 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012); In re: Androgel Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 655 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
See In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376, 382–383 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
See In re Holiday Magic Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 806 (J.P.M.L. 1973).

See In re Air Crash Near Edgartown, Mass., on October 6, 2000, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Virginia Precast/Hydrotile Machinery Co. Contract Litigation, 1993 WL 54192 (J.P.M.L. 1993); In re Natural Resources Fund, Inc., Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1403, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
See, e.g., In re South Cent. States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1127 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
See, e.g., In re South Cent. States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1127 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Library Editions of Children's Books, 297 F. Supp. 385, 387 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See In re Scientific Control Corp. Securities Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 791, 793 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
See In re AMF Computerized Cash Register Contract Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1404, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
Lexecon Inc. v. Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, 523 U.S. 26, 118 S. Ct. 956, 140 L. Ed. 2d 62 (1998). Lexecon is discussed in greater detail in § 3:14.
See Lexecon Inc. v. Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, 523 U.S. 26, 118 S. Ct. 956, 140 L. Ed. 2d 62 (1998).
See In re Best Buy Co., Inc., California Song-Beverly Credit Card Act Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2011).
